head.title: Art in Review; Gedi Sibony and Josh Smith

hedline.hl1: Art in Review; Gedi Sibony and Josh Smith

abstract.p: Ken Johnson reviews Gedi Sibony and Josh Smith exhibition at Harris Lieberman (S)

block.p: Harris Lieberman 89 Vandam Street, near Greenwich Street, SoHo Through May 6

Gedi Sibony and Josh Smith each make art that arouses in the viewer a mildly irate bemusement. Mr. Sibony is currently in the Whitney Biennial, and Mr. Smith has been in exhibitions at the maverick gallery Reena Spaulings Fine Art.
Harris Lieberman 89 Vandam Street, near Greenwich Street, SoHo Through May 6

Gedi Sibony and Josh Smith each make art that arouses in the viewer a mildly irate bemusement. Mr. Sibony is currently in the Whitney Biennial, and Mr. Smith has been in exhibitions at the maverick gallery Reena Spaulings Fine Art.

Nominally a painter, Mr. Smith roughly paints his own name in large, blocky letters over collages made from newspaper pages and photocopied ephemera or on stretched, store-bought printed fabric. These works are totally uninteresting visually, so the point -- a stunningly sophomoric one -- is presumably to mock the bourgeois overvaluation of the big-name artist's signature.

Mr. Sibony, a sculptor, has seemingly casually placed various sorts of flat raw material -- cardboard, plywood, sheetrock, perforated metal -- in different parts of the gallery. He has also partly covered one room's floor with carpet, which extends up a narrow section of wall. And he has removed a wall section so that you can see into a normally hidden dark, empty space. On the floor in one room of the gallery lies a scrap of polyethylene plastic that looks like a piece of rubbish gallery workers forgot to pick up.

Mr. Sibony might be a kind of formalist who, like Richard Tuttle, prompts a heightened attention to sensory experience. But in the company of Mr. Smith, he seems like a Duchampian provocateur who challenges the viewer to rethink his or her assumptions about the nature and purpose of art. If you think that is still an interesting thing to do, then you may enjoy this otherwise enervating show.
